description: Large hydraulic system employed with multiple leats. Probably this mine did not continue operations into the imperial period. Roads were built connecting the settlements and mines as well as providing extra regional travel. Nearby are located stone structures which could be workers' hamlets (over 250 groups). Pliny notes a Rebublican law forbidding the use of more than 5000 workers in a single mine, which might indicate that prior to this rule more had been present.

Known as Phaeno in Roman times. A copper mining site located in the Wadi Faynan off the Wadi ‘Arabah. Peak production was in the fourth century which is later than most mining sites especially those in the western empire. The underground mining was extensive and the mine of Umm al-Amad is one of the largest known mine galleries in the Roman empire. An estimated 2,500-7,000 tons of copper were produced here.

description: A Roman gold mine located in Pumsaint, Wales operating from the first through the third century. The nearby fort (2 ha) probably oversaw the mining operation and suggest imperial control of the mines. However civilian contractors probably worked the mines later. A large hydraulic system was set up with multiple tanks and 5 aqueducts, one over 11 km in length, for exploiting the opencast pits. Underground mining also took place to considerable depths and pieces of a water wheel used to drain the mines were found in the 1930’s. Bath house and workshops found near the mines. The Carreg Pumpsaint is an anvil stone from a Roman ore-crushing machine, located next to a heap of crushed ore slimes, and a wheel-race fed from a dammed pond.

Roads, settlements and forts created by specialist contractors brought in after military establishment. 33 denarii of Antonius Pius and coins of Constantine were found. Roads and track ways leading between Great Orme and the Chester (Deva) fort.
notes: See for list of finds: http://shropshirehistory.com/other/llanymynech.htm

locationDataSource: Satellite imagery and site visit
locationNotes: On the south slope of the ridge immediately W of the motorway intersection W of Pradorrey.
description: A series of small scale workings along the slope of the ridge to the W of the motorway intersection by Pradorrey. A channel comes from the W, and at least six small-scale ditches divert from it down the slope to the south. These look either like prospections, or were very small-scale mining operations. Probably the channel continued eastward to feed the mine at Pradorrey, but the intervening stretch has been destroyed by the motorway intersection.
